title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Who am I?







I am the inaugural director of the Dominguez Center for Data Science at Bucknell University.

This is my first administrative gig.

We are building it up to be the campus hub for data science practice, support, and community.
I also spend my days figuring out our relationship to AI.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science
text:
Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science

Have had sabbaticals with

The Forest Service Forest Inventory and Analysis Program
The Bureau of Labor Statistics

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science
text: Research Interests: Where survey statistics meets data science

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Some Reflections





I have been on the job market a few times and so have thoughts on how to put together a good packet.
Happy to compare and contrast the different roles I’ve held:

Assistant to associate professor at small liberal arts colleges
Teaching faculty at a research university
Administrator for a data science center

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Some Reflections





It is okay to move and it is okay to stay.

Don’t strive for the perfect fit.

The people you work with regularly are important.

You have less control over your departmental colleagues.
You have more control over your research collaborators.

Choose your service commitments wisely.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Excited to chat about the application process!
text: Excited to chat about the application process!

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Data Literacy


What is data literacy?



It is not the same as mathematical literacy.



XXX

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Data in Stat 100
Will use a wide-range of real and relevant data examples

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Data in Stat 100







I understand that some of these topics have likely had profound impacts on your lives.
We will focus class time on the key course objectives but will use these current topics to empower ourselves and to see how we can productively participate with data.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Statistical Thinking



Understanding the importance of context.



 Context explains the Monday jumps in the COVID counts.





How we encode information in a graph should be driven by our research question.



 Design choices impact the conclusions the viewer draws.





How the data are collected impacts the conclusions we can draw.



 Voluntary COVID test results don’t likely provide good estimates of COVID prevalence.





Often we are using a sample of data to say something about a larger group. In this case, we should measure how certain our estimates are!



 We will learn to compute and interpret certainty estimates (like those in the wastewater graph) later in the course!

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Statistical Thinking

About developing reasoning (not just learning definitions and formulae).
Developing our statistical thinking skills will allow us to soundly extract knowledge from data!
Statistical thinking requires judgment that takes time to develop.

Will see examples and practice applying statistical thinking throughout the course.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
What are/is Data?



“‘Raw data’ is an oxymoron.” – Lisa Gitelman



“Data … is information made tractable.” – Catherine D’Ignazio and Lauren Klein

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Hand-Drawn Data Viz

Once we have collected data, a common next step is to visualize it.
Two key aspects of data visualization:

Determining how you want to display the data.
Figuring out how to tell the computer to do that mapping.

Hand-drawn data visualizations allow us to focus on the first part with full control over the creative process!

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Hand-Drawn Data Viz Examples
Dear Data

“Each week, and for a year, we collected and measured a particular type of data about our lives, used this data to make a drawing on a postcard-sized sheet of paper, and then dropped the postcard in an English”postbox” (Stefanie) or an American “mailbox” (Giorgia)!“

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Goal: By next Wed, collect data from your life so that you can visualize it on P-Set 1.
text:
Goal: By next Wed, collect data from your life so that you can visualize it on P-Set 1.



Recommendations


Store the data in your favorite spreadsheet program (Google Sheets, Numbers, Excel).
Determine what your cases/observations will be.
Collect data on more variables than you will likely visualize. It is hard to know beforehand what the interesting relationships will be.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Elevator Speeches

Come to class with 2 versions (one for educated non-expert and one for general public).

Make sure to give your name, year, and major.
Pick a data project for your speech. (It can be your 306 project, summer work, DCDS project, etc.)
Follow the advice in the readings for the week.
Make sure to avoid jargon and only provide technical information if needed.
Connect your project to broad interest.
Each speech should be 2 - 3 minutes long and make sure to speak at a reasonable pace.
Be ready for a follow-up question.

Incorporate feedback and then create a recording of both your speeches.

Upload to Google Drive. Share the link with me via Google Drive and on Gradescope.
Due by 10am next Tuesday (November 4th).

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Why create a data visualization?


To explore the data.


To summarize the data.


To showcase trends and make comparisons.


To tell a story.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Challenger

On January 27th, 1986, engineers from Morton Thiokol recommended NASA delay launch of space shuttle Challenger due to cold weather.

Believed cold weather impacted the o-rings that held the rockets together.
Used 13 charts in their argument.

After a two hour conference call, the engineer’s recommendation was overruled due to lack of persuasive evidence and the launch proceeded.
The Challenger exploded 73 seconds into launch.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Challenger
Here’s one of those charts.

title: DATA/MATH 306

Challenger

Challenger

For more information on this example and other examples, check out Tufte’s book.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Data Viz: Science & Tech
Let’s focus on visually telling data stories related to climate change.

What are some properties of a good data visualization?
What are some properties of a bad data visualization?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Activity

For each visualization:

Determine the story.
How effective is the data visualization at telling that story?
What additional context is provided to help the viewer understand the story?
Decide what properties it has and give it the appropriate sticker(s).

All of these graphs came from the New York Times’ “What’s Going on in this Graph?” Series

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Lessons

Did we all see the same stories?
Did we all have the same opinions about the visualizations?
A compelling visual can help us better understand and remember a data story.

Understand your audience.
Think carefully about the design choices.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Learning Objectives
You will engage in collaborative, data science projects. Upon successful completion of this course, you will be able to:

Conduct a full data analysis project.
Communicate about your data work at a variety of levels and via a variety of formats including short presentations, longer presentations, and written reports.
Think statistically about data and research questions.
Collaborate on projects with a reproducible workflow.
Run a productive consulting meeting.
Undertake future projects with greater independence.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Policies

Make sure to check the course site for policies related to regrades, late work, attendance, technology, accommodations.
But let’s talk AI…

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
AI Policy
While A.I. tools, such as ChatGPT, are being used to generate code, analyze data, and write essays, goals of this course are to develop your own ability to write code, to thoughtfully extract knowledge from data, and to communicate your findings.
You may use AI in these course activities:

Providing feedback on their writing. The original draft should be your work but you can ask for feedback from AI and incorporate that feedback into the revision.
Providing coding suggestions or revisions. You are responsible for understanding every line of code in your project, regardless of whether it was written by you, your project members, your mentor, or AI.
Brainstorming ideas for your project.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
AI Policy
You may not use AI in these ways:

Writing the initial draft or whole paragraphs of a writing assignment or your technical report.
Writing large blocks of code.


If you do use AI in your project or on an assignment, please include an AI citation that provides: prompt, AI tool, company, date.


If you are in doubt as to whether you are using AI appropriately in this course, I encourage you to meet with me for a discussion. Violations of this policy will be considered academic misconduct.

Project goals: What the stakeholder mentor wants to accomplish.

Desired deliverables: Vary by project but all include a well-documented repository, technical report, and a final presentation (Dec 15th 9am - 11am).
Roles and expectations for each person on the team.
Research plan
Communication


Please read over the project charters and complete the Background and Interest Survey by noon tomorrow!

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Data Ethics

Considered a subfield of applied ethics.
Data ethics studies and evaluates moral problems related to:

Data
Algorithms
Corresponding Practices

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Ethical Guidelines
American Statistical Association have published Ethical Guidelines for Statistical Practice
Purpose of the Guidelines:

“The ethical guidelines aim to promote accountability by informing those who rely on any aspects of statistical practice of the standards they should expect. Society benefits from informed judgments supported by ethical statistical practice. All statistical practitioners are expected to follow these guidelines and encourage others to do the same.


In some situations, guideline principles may require balancing competing interests. If an unexpected ethical challenge arises, the ethical practitioner seeks guidance, not exceptions, in the guidelines. To justify unethical behaviors, or to exploit gaps in the guidelines, is unprofessional and inconsistent with these guidelines.”

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
OkCupid Example
In 2016, a group of researchers publicly released a dataset of nearly 70,000 users of the online dating site OkCupid. The dataset included several variables such as username, age, gender, location, relationship interests, and personality traits. When asked whether or not the researchers had tried to anonymize the data, the researchers said “No. Data is already public” and “Some may object to the ethics of gathering and releasing this data. However, all the data found in the dataset are or were already publicly available, so releasing this dataset merely presents it is a more useful form.”

What is your reaction to the researchers’ statement?
Do you think users of social media platforms are adequately informed as to how their data might be collected, stored, and used?
Who benefits from this type of large-scale collection of personal data? Who is harmed? What might those harms or benefits look like?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Model for Predicting Clicks
Suppose that a job site created a machine learning model that predicts the likelihood that someone will interact with a job posting. Their model finds that people from a certain demographic group are more likely to interact with a nannying job post than a construction job post. A new person from that demographic group engages with the job site and based on the predictive model, the job site shows nannying job posts to them instead of construction job posts.

What is algorithmic bias? Describe how algorithmic bias relates to the given example.
What other ethical issues are present in this example?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Publish or Perish: Replicability
The aphorism “publish or perish” refers to the intense pressure faced by researchers to publish academic work in order to sustain their career. At the same time, the most pres- tigious journals in a scientific field receive many more submissions than can be published, leading to a high rejection rate.

Describe two ways in which the competition to publish has contributed to the replicability crisis.
Who benefits when results that might not replicate are published? Who is harmed? What might those harms or benefits look like?
What is the best way to ensure that science produces both novel findings and replicable results?
Should all scientists be required to engage in replication work or only a select group? What are potential advantages and disadvantages of either option?

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Modeling & Inference Step: Start with Modeling
text:
Modeling & Inference Step: Start with Modeling

Descriptive Models: Describe the data.
Inferential & Explanatory Models: Explore a specific hypothesis and explain how variables relate.
Predictive Models: Predict new data well.


Questions:


What types of models have you seen in your courses here at Bucknell?
How could models be useful for your project?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Inferential Models in Intro Stats
Problem Set-up: In a 1995 study, Hecht and LeFrance examined the effect of a smile on the leniency of disciplinary action for wrongdoers. Participants in the experiment took on the role of members of a college disciplinary panel judging students accused of cheating. For each suspect, along with a description of the offense, a picture was provided with either a smile or neutral facial expression. A leniency score was calculated based on the disciplinary decisions made by the participants. Can a simple smile have an effect on punishment assigned following an infraction?
Question: What inferential model might we use to answer this question?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Inference

Regardless of your modeling goals, you will want to draw conclusions about some group/population.
Question: Do you have census data for your project?




If yes, then likely don’t need measures of uncertainty for estimation but still need to assess model quality/accuracy.
Should still consider if there is a broader group you’d like to generalize to.



If no, then you do need measures of uncertainty and to assess model quality/accuracy.
Should consider how representative the sample is of the population.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Modeling Goal: Descriptive, Inferential/Explanatory, or Predictive?
text: Modeling Goal: Descriptive, Inferential/Explanatory, or Predictive?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text: Which Model is Best? Why?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Model Goals: Form and Variables
Problem Set-up: The Massachusetts Comprehensive Assessment System (MCAS) is a standardized exam administered to students in the state of Massachusetts since 1993. Under law, students educated with public funds are required to participate in statewide testing. Students take exams according to their grade level in subjects such as Mathematics and English Language Arts; passing grades on the Grade 10 MCAS are required for high school graduation. Exam results are used to check student progress as well as measure school and district performance.

Describe a scenario where data from the 2025 Grade 10 Mathematics MCAS could be used to explore achievement gaps. Focus on inferential/explanatory modeling and discuss what variables and model form you might consider.
Reconsider the goal of building a model to explore achievement gaps but this time from a predictive perspective. How might the model form and variables used differ from those in (a) if your modeling goal is now predictive?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Model Goals: Form and Variables
Problem Set-up: The Massachusetts Comprehensive Assessment System (MCAS) is a standardized exam administered to students in the state of Massachusetts since 1993. Under law, students educated with public funds are required to participate in statewide testing. Students take exams according to their grade level in subjects such as Mathematics and English Language Arts; passing grades on the Grade 10 MCAS are required for high school graduation. Exam results are used to check student progress as well as measure school and district performance.

Discuss the trade-offs between a simple, interpretable model and a complex, black box model for a data science consulting project. When should you choose one over the other?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Variable Choices
Problem Set-up: Suppose you are a consultant and have a healthcare client who wants a model to predict patient no-show rates so that they can optimize scheduling. During the modeling process, you discover that a patient’s zip code is a highly predictive variable.

Discuss the positive and negative consequences of including versus excluding zip code from the model.
Brainstorm what other variables zip code might be a proxy for. Which of these variables might the healthcare client have access to and would you consider including in the model instead of zip code?

Discussion leaders by rule in Schedule

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Project Groups
Can find your group assignments here

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Why Positron?










Positron is a new data science tool for writing code and exploring data.
You can use R or Python.
Go here to download R. (I will also show you how to interact with Python but the demos will be in R today.)
Go here to download Positron.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
DATA 306 git Experience










It takes some time to get comfortable with git. We have time.
Use office hours if you get stuck on any of the steps today!

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
git and GitHub



git: Version control system

Think fancier type of Track Changes.

GitHub: Hosting service for git projects (which are called repositories)

Think fancier type of DropBox or Google Drive.

Useful resource when getting started: https://happygitwithr.com/

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Manual Version Control



But I already do version control…

draft.Rmd, draft2.Rmd, final.Rmd, realFinal.Rmd, REALLYVERYREALFinal.Rmd…

Issues with this version of version control:

Hard to know how these files relate.
Hard to extend this approach to working with others.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Git Real

Git is a decentralized version control system.

Each collaborator has a complete version of the repo.
Everyone can work offline and simultaneously.
GitHub holds the master copy.

git is not friendly and can be frustrating.

BUT, the version control and collaborative rewards are big!

GitHub.com is a great place to develop an online presence.

In DATA 306, we will default to keeping the work private.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
A Hot Mess is Okay

If you end up with a mess of errors, then don’t worry but come see one of the instructors for help.

It happens to everyone.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: A Github Repo = Project/Folder on Your Computer
text:
A Github Repo = Project/Folder on Your Computer

A repo, short for repository, is the folder that contains all of the files for the project on GitHub.com.
Under the Bucknell-DATA306-F25 GitHub Organization you will have access to 3 repos:

work-username: Just you and I can access
class-site: The whole class can access
projectname: Your team, stakeholder (possibly), and I can access

For each repo, you should sync with a folder on your computer.

We will all do this together for work-username today.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Steps to Get Started


Once-Per-Computer/Server:

Install git on your computer.
Get your local git talking to GitHub.


Once-Per-Project:

Create a repo on GitHub.

I did this step for us.

Create a version controlled Project that is synced with the GitHub repo.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Git via Positron + R

So that the workflow is the same for everyone:

Open Positron.
Start an R session.

You will be able to toggle to Python after we have synced with GitHub.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Check if git is install on your computer
text:
Check if git is install on your computer
In Terminal, type

which git

git --version





If you receive an answer, then git is already install! 🎉





If the reply is git: command not found (or similar), then

Windows: Visit https://gitforwindows.org/
Macs: In the Terminal type




xcode-select --install    



Restart your session.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Introduce Yourself to Git
Install the packages usethis and gitcreds:

install.packages(c("usethis", "gitcreds"))

In your R console, modify and run the following code to introduce yourself to git

usethis::use_git_config(user.name = "mcconvil", 
               user.email = "k.mcconville@bucknell.edu")

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Personal Access Token Time


To interact with GitHub, you need to include credentials.

Personal Access Token (PAT)

In your R console, run



usethis::create_github_token()



Should take you to GitHub.
Select “repo”, “user”, and “workflow” for the scopes.
Click “Generate token”.
Store it by running the following in the R Console:



gitcreds::gitcreds_set()

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Sync GitHub.com repo and a Project
text:
Sync GitHub.com repo and a Project
In your repo on GitHub.com:


Click on the green clone or download button.
Copy the given url for “Clone with HTTPS”.


In Positron:


In the Welcome pane, select “New from Git…”
Paste in the url.
Select “Browse…” and select a logical place on your computer for the repository folder.
Hit the “OK” button.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Workflow
Once your GitHub repo and RStudio project are synced, here’s your workflow:

On the left menu, select “Source Control”.
Under the three dots associated with “CHANGES”, select Pull.

This will pull the most recent version of the repo from GitHub to your local folder.

Do some work on your project and save it.
In the “Source Control”, select the “+” (stage changes) button.
Include a quick note, Commit Message to summarize the motivation for the changes.
Select Commit & Push to send your work to GitHub.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Test the waters: Let’s go through the workflow.
text:
Test the waters: Let’s go through the workflow.


Pull. (Yes, there is nothing to pull yet but it is always good practice to start here.)
Click on the ReadMe.
Add something to the ReadMe.
Stage the changes to the ReadMe.
Put in a commit message.
Commit & Push.


Look for updates in the ReadMe on GitHub.com.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Git Collaboration: Merge conflicts

What if my collaborators and I both make changes?

Scenario: Your collaborator makes changes to a file, commits, and pushes to GitHub. You also modify that file, commit and push.

Result: Your push will fail because there’s a commit on GitHub that you don’t have.

Usual Solution: Pull and usually git will merge their work nicely with yours. Then push. If that doesn’t work, you have a merge conflict. Let’s cross that bridge when we get there.

How to avoid merge conflicts?

Always pull when you are going to work on your project.
Always commit and push when you are done even if you made small changes.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Example Tasks

Create 20 exploratory graphs and relate back to research question/problem.
Determine and complete data cleaning tasks (e.g., collapse categorical variable into coarser bins, join datasets, recode -99s to NA, …).
Make sure everyone on the team (including Kelly) has the cleaned, wrangled dataset. Make sure the script that outlines all wrangling steps is included in the repository.
Create a data dictionary and share in our GitHub repository.
Split data into training and testing splits. Make sure everyone on the team (including Kelly) has access and the script to split the data is the repository.
Determine model form and variables to include in models. (Check with Kelly before moving to modeling.)
Genomics: Start creating protocol for processing genes with otb.
AI Personas: Create more “representative” Bucknell personas. Give personas part of the MyVoice survey. Compare closed and open question responses to the true results.

Initial Project Meeting with Stakeholder

Structure of the meeting

Listen carefully and ask follow-up questions.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Plan for Next Three Classes

Today: Data Ethics Discussion
Week 9, Tues: Lab Day/Check-ins
Week 9, Thurs: Mock Consulting Sessions with DCDS Advisory Board Members

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Data Ethics

Ethics considers normative questions:

What should a person morally value?
What decision should a person make in a given context?

The readings broke data science ethics into evaluating moral problems related to:

Data
Algorithms
Corresponding Practices

Impacts several (all?) stages of the data analysis process.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Guidelines
American Statistical Association have published Ethical Guidelines for Statistical Practice
Purpose of the Guidelines:

“The ethical guidelines aim to promote accountability by informing those who rely on any aspects of statistical practice of the standards they should expect. Society benefits from informed judgments supported by ethical statistical practice. All statistical practitioners are expected to follow these guidelines and encourage others to do the same.


In some situations, guideline principles may require balancing competing interests. If an unexpected ethical challenge arises, the ethical practitioner seeks guidance, not exceptions, in the guidelines. To justify unethical behaviors, or to exploit gaps in the guidelines, is unprofessional and inconsistent with these guidelines.”

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Cambridge Analytica
Review the American Statistical Association’s Ethical Guidelines and identify at least two guidelines that were violated by the Cambridge Analytica study.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
OkCupid Example
In 2016, a group of researchers publicly released a dataset of nearly 70,000 users of the online dating site OkCupid. The dataset included several variables such as username, age, gender, location, relationship interests, and personality traits. When asked whether or not the researchers had tried to anonymize the data, the researchers said “No. Data is already public” and “Some may object to the ethics of gathering and releasing this data. However, all the data found in the dataset are or were already publicly available, so releasing this dataset merely presents it is a more useful form.”

What is your reaction to the researchers’ statement?
Do you think users of social media platforms are adequately informed as to how their data might be collected, stored, and used?
Who benefits from this type of large-scale collection of personal data? Who is harmed? What might those harms or benefits look like?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Model for Predicting Clicks
Suppose that a job site created a machine learning model that predicts the likelihood that someone will interact with a job posting. Their model finds that people from a certain demographic group are more likely to interact with a nannying job post than a construction job post. A new person from that demographic group engages with the job site and based on the predictive model, the job site shows nannying job posts to them instead of construction job posts.
a. What is algorithmic bias? Describe how algorithmic bias relates to the given example. b. What other ethical issues are present in this example? c. For each ethical issue, address which stage of the data analysis process they align with.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Publish or Perish: Replicability
The aphorism “publish or perish” refers to the intense pressure faced by researchers to publish academic work in order to sustain their career. At the same time, the most pres- tigious journals in a scientific field receive many more submissions than can be published, leading to a high rejection rate.

Describe two ways in which the competition to publish has contributed to the replicability crisis.
Who benefits when results that might not replicate are published? Who is harmed? What might those harms or benefits look like?
What is the best way to ensure that science produces both novel findings and replicable results?
Should all scientists be required to engage in replication work or only a select group? What are potential advantages and disadvantages of either option?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Data in Context
Consider the following excerpt from the ASA Ethical Guides Section on responsibilities to research subjects, data subjects, or those directly affected by statistical practices: “The ethical statistical practitioner considers the impact of statistical practice on society, groups, and individuals. Statisticians should recognize that statistical practice could adversely affect groups or the public perception of groups, including marginalized groups. Statisticians should contemplate, and be sensitive to, the manner in which information is framed to avoid disproportionate harm to vulnerable groups.”

In the article “Racial Health Disparities and Covid-19—Caution and Context”, the authors argue that while it is important to document racial disparity data, such data need to be contextualized with adequate analysis in order to avoid perpetuating harmful stereotypes. Suppose you were tasked with creating an interactive map of COVID data. What additional context would be important to provide as an ethical data scientist?
Who will be impacted by your project? How will they benefit? How might they be harmed? What can your team do to minimize the harms and maximize the benefits?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Team Leader Duties

Team leaders this week: team leader spreadsheet
Each week we will rotate who is the Team Leader.

Team Leader will be in-charge of synthesizing group work, making sure everyone is on the same page, creating the week’s To Do list via Issues, scheduling meetings, organizing the group’s presentation.

This week’s Team Leaders’ tasks:

Schedule a time between now and 10pm on Monday to discuss the initial project reading with your group mates.
Be in-charge of the activity we run in class on Thursday.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Projects

Will utilize a wide variety of techniques across the different projects.
Be prepared to do some independent learning. Each group will be using different techniques that we likely won’t cover explicitly in-class.
But, remember that there are many avenues for help!

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Project Management
Utilize the following from Wilson et al (2017):

Data management

Save the raw data.
Create an tidy, analysis-friendly dataset and use a non-proprietary format.
Record all steps used to process data.
Create a data dictionary.



We will not be putting the project data in our GitHub repositories and will only store these files locally.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Project Management
Utilize the following from Wilson et al (2017):

Writing code

Place a brief explanatory comment at the start of every program. (See example in paper.)
Look for well-maintained packages to use.
Give functions and variables meaningful names.

Ex: Replace var1 with college_name

Make dependencies explicit.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Project Management
Utilize the following from Wilson et al (2017):

Collaboration

Create overview of project in the README
Use Project and Issues features to create to-do lists.

Project organization

Let’s walk through one of the project repos.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Project Management
Utilize the following from Wilson et al (2017):

Track changes via Github

Keep changes small.
Share changes frequently.

Writing

Write about your work early and often.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Reproducibility

Reproducible versus replicable



“Reproducibility involves being able to recalculate the exact numbers in a data analysis using the code and raw data provided by the analyst.” (Leek, 2015)



Not the same as correctness!

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Write Readable Code

It is important to write readable code.

Follow a specific convention.
Use spaces liberally.

Avoid . in object names.

Example: Tidyverse Style Guide.
As a group, decide on a style convention. I don’t want to see three or four different conventions for a given project.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Writing Readable Code

“Use common sense and BE CONSISTENT.


If you are editing code, take a few minutes to look at the code around you and determine its style. If others use spaces around their if clauses, you should, too. If their comments have little boxes of stars around them, make your comments have little boxes of stars around them, too.


The point of having style guidelines is to have a common vocabulary of coding so people can concentrate on what you are saying, rather than on how you are saying it.


We present global style rules here so people know the vocabulary. But local style is also important. If code you add to a file looks drastically different from the existing code around it, the discontinuity will throw readers out of their rhythm when they go to read it. Try to avoid this.” –Google Style Guide

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:

git: Version control system

Think fancier type of Track Changes.

GitHub: Hosting service for git projects (which are called repositories)

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Git Collaboration: Merge conflicts

What if my collaborators and I both make changes?

Scenario: Your collaborator makes changes to a file, commits, and pushes to GitHub. You also modify that file, commit and push.

Result: Your push will fail because there’s a commit on GitHub that you don’t have.

Usual Solution: Pull and usually git will merge their work nicely with yours. Then push. If that doesn’t work, you have a merge conflict. Let’s cross that bridge when we get there.

How to avoid merge conflicts?

Always pull when you are going to work on your project.
Always commit and push when you are done even if you made small changes.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Some Recommendations as You are Getting Comfortable with Git
text:
Some Recommendations as You are Getting Comfortable with Git

Pull early and often.
Use git early and often.

We get better with practice.

Don’t all work on the same document as that will increase your changes of a merge conflict.

Let the team leader synthesize each person’s work into one document.

Merge conflicts will happen. Work with me and your group members to resolve them.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Reading Articles/Research Prompt

Get in your research groups and try to sync your project repo with a folder on your computer.

Help each other out.
I will come over to check on each group and to schedule your first meeting with your project stakeholder.

Orient yourself in your project repo and determine where and how you want to store the work you do this week.
Go through your project prompt more slowly and start a list of the central terms/ideas, especially ones you don’t know.
Discuss these ideas as a group.
Start reading the initial project articles and practicing the “reading to write” concepts from CwD.

Note: Some of the initial articles don’t have much or any data in them.

Team leader: Schedule a time for the group members to meet and discuss the reading.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Plan for Today

Topics to discuss:

Confirmatory studies versus exploratory studies
Exploratory data analysis

Demos in Positron
EDA activity

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Types of Data Projects
What is the difference between confirmatory and exploratory studies?


Confirmatory Studies

Classical view of statistical process
Start with hypotheses and then use data to assess the accuracy of the hypotheses.


Exploratory Studies

Start with the data and use the data to generate hypotheses.



Questions:


Pros and cons of each type?
Under which type does your project fall?

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Avoiding Overfitting the Data/P-Hacking in Exploratory Studies
text:
Avoiding Overfitting the Data/P-Hacking in Exploratory Studies




Split your data into two sets:

Training set: Data to mine
Test set: Data to apply your final models to.







Typically 70/30 or 80/20 split.
Question: How should you decide what data goes into the training set versus the test set?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)

All studies, exploratory or confirmatory, should include a robust exploration stage.

Might be more constrained for confirmatory studies.

EDA Goals:

Look for data quality issues (missingness, censored data, mislabeled data, representativity, …).
Discover trends in the data (within one variable, between 2+ variables).

There is no perfect checklist for EDA.
It is a VERY iterative process.

title: DATA/MATH 306
section: Qualities of an Effective Data Scientist
text:
Qualities of an Effective Data Scientist






I think one is missing: Curiosity!

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
General (Incomplete) EDA Checklist
Disclaimer: Not every item on this list will work for every project.

Formulate a few questions you want to answer with your explorations. Typical questions:

What type of variation occurs within the variables?
What type of variation occurs between the variables?

Check the size of the data.

Do you have the correct number of observations and variable?

Spend time exploring how the data are coded.

Do the variables have the correct classification in R or Python?

Summarize from many angles.

What are typical values?
Any red flags? If so, explore different subsets of the data.
What information is gained from these summaries?

title: DATA/MATH 306
text:
General (Incomplete) EDA Checklist

Validate with at least one external data source.

Are my summaries reasonably similar to the external source? If not, why not?

Make many plots.

Are there any unusual patterns? If so, what might explain them?
What information is gained from these plots?
Go back and compute additional summary statistics based on what you learned from the plots.

Tidy

Determine what data wrangling steps should go into creating a tidy version of the data.

Try the easy solution.

Try to at least partially answer some of your research questions via your EDA output.

title: DATA/MATH 306
text: EDA Activity
